description: A massive thunderstorm forecast to hit Sydney has missed the city and headed out to sea, after severe weather warnings for parts of New South Wales and Melbourne were also downgraded.
title: Sydney and Melbourne narrowly miss wild weather with thunderstorms and hail
title_page: Sydney and Melbourne narrowly miss wild weather with thunderstorms and hail | Daily Mail Online
text:
A massive thunderstorm forecast to hit Sydney has missed the city and headed out to sea, after severe weather warnings for parts of New South Wales and Melbourne were also downgraded.
The Bureau of Meteorology had earlier warned Sydney would be smashed by huge hailstones and heavy rain as storms roll across the city from about 6pm.
A severe storm warning was also issued for parts of New South Wales, as experts advised residents to stay indoors throughout the extreme conditions.
Scroll down for video
Massive thunderstorms are set to smash Sydney and Melbourne on Monday evening, with the Bureau of Meteorology predicting wild weather on the east coast
A warning was also issued for Melbourne and parts of Victoria, including regional cities Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Mildura.
The State Emergency Service warns that residents should stay clear of fallen powerlines, secure loose objects around their homes, stay indoors if possible or avoid sheltering under trees and switch off computers and appliances.
Drivers were also advised to take extra care on the road during the storms.
It comes after people sweated through a scorching heatwave earlier in the days, as temperatures soared into the high 30s and low 40s.
The Bureau of Meteorology warned Sydney will be hit by huge hailstones and heavy rain as storms roll across the city from about 6pm
The New South Wales warning covered a large area of the coast near Sydney, and stretched as far south as Wollongong and north to Newcastle
Hot air from Western Australia that is now moving east pushed temperatures across the outback well into the upper 30s on Sunday and they will continue to rise until a cooler front takes over on Friday.
The interior and western areas of New South Wales and northern Victoria will be the hottest areas in Australia with temperatures possibly reaching 45 beginning Monday until Wednesday, Bureau of Meteorology Forecaster Andrew Haigh said.
‘There will be persistent hot temperatures in Western inland of NSW west of the Great Dividing Range – from Mildura to Wagga Wagga,’ he said.
